context: Adjacent to the palace is <a0_0><a4_0><b9_0>the Royal Mews<b9_0/><a4_0/><a0_0/>, also designed by <a3_0><b8_0>Nash<b8_0/><a3_0/>, where the royal carriages, including the Gold State Coach, are housed. This rococo gilt coach, designed by <a5_0><b10_0>Sir William Chambers<b10_0/><a5_0/> in 1760, has painted panels by G. B. Cipriani. It was first used for the State Opening of Parliament by George III in <a1_0><a6_0><b11_0>1762<b11_0/><a6_0/><a1_0/> and has been used by the monarch for every coronation since George IV. It was last used for the Golden Jubilee of Elizabeth II. Also housed in the mews are the coach <a2_0><a7_0><b12_0>horses<b12_0/><a7_0/><a2_0/> used at royal ceremonial processions.
